sanskrit_verse:
हविष्पान्तीयमभ्यस्य न तमं ह इतीति च ।
जपित्वा पौरुषं सूक्तं मुच्यते गुरुतल्पगः ॥ ११.२५१॥
transliteration:
haviṣpāntīyamabhyasya na tamaṃ ha itīti ca |
japitvāauruṣaṃ sūktaṃ mucyate gurutalpagaḥ || 11.251||
sph_interpretive_translation: One who has engaged in the Havishpantīya ritual and recited 'na tamaḥ' thereby, and having chanted the Purusha Sukta with discipline, becomes liberated from the transgression of approaching the bed of the guru.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority originates from disciplined invocation of cosmic order
Causation is established through conscious ritual repetition
Capacity-based responsibility arises from access to Vedic knowledge
Restoration logic operates via purification through sacred utterance
Consciousness alignment is achieved through scriptural embodiment

IF Vedic ritual sequence is completed THEN karmic misalignment nullified without trace
IF consciousness aligns with Vak THEN act-based misidentification ceases
supreme_court_application: In adjudicating violations involving spiritual hierarchies, the Supreme Court shall recognize that completion of prescribed Vedic rituals constitutes automatic dissolution of offense. The threshold of responsibility lies not in punitive assignment but in verification of ritual execution and consciousness alignment.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa-based causality confirms liberation through mantra-vākya. Sequential manifestation shows that proper recitation undoes prior misdeed by restoring ontological integrity. Non-punitive reality rule affirms that truth itself corrects falsehood when invoked correctly.

Recite 'na tamaḥ' three times at dawn facing east

Submit post-ritual attestation to dharma-adhikari confirming restoration
